Dictionary Info Guide

Chapter 4

ad
(takes accusative)
to/toward
amō
amāre
to love or like
ascendō
ascendere
to go up, climb up
derivative(s): ascension
audiō
audīre
to hear
derivative(s): audition, audience
cōnspiciō
cōnspicere
to notice
derivative(s): conspicuous
dormiō
dormīre
to sleep
derivative(s): dormant, dormitory
ex/ē
(takes ablative)
out of
fragor
fragoris m.
crash
fūrtim
sneakily
derivative(s): furtive, furtively
magnus
magna, magnum
big, loud, great
derivative(s): magnanimous
molestus
molesta, molestum
annoying
nihil
n.
nothing
note: can be nominative or accusative
derivative(s): annihilate, nihilist
rāmus
rāmī m.
branch
rideō
ridēre
to laugh
tē
you (accusative)
terreō
terrēre
to frighten
(something else)
derivative(s): terrify
tū
you (nominative)
tum
then
vexō
vexāre
to annoy
derivative(s): vexatious, vexation
videō
vidēre
to see
derivative(s): vision, evidence
vox
vocis f.
voice
derivative(s): vocalize

Prepositional Phrases

ad vīllam
(accusative singular)
to the house
ad vīllās
(accusative plural)
to the houses
ex agrīs
(ablative plural)
out of the fields
ex agrō
(ablative singular)
out of the field

Other Phrases

magnā voce
in a loud voice

Infinitives

amāre
1st Conjugation
to love
ascendere
3rd Conjugation
to go up, climb up
dormīre
4th Conjugation
to sleep
terrēre
2nd Conjugation
to frighten
vexāre
1st Conjugation
to annoy
vidēre
2nd Conjugation
to see
